column4: to be a little more specif in regards to my original issue: is there any way to remove incomplete package downloads?
Hm, apt-get clean, maybe?
apt-get clean normally removes the package files (e.g. the files used to install stuff, not the actual files that are installed). It'd make sense to me for it to clean up partials as well.
Do you have any other synaptic, apt-get, etc, running?
after running clean i am still getting these problems, and i am pretty sure they didnt even have a change to start downloading?
Ugh, I've been here before...
It looks like one of your packages failed to install.
Maybe try sudo aptitude -reinstall on the package.
the power cord thing is actually good news, since the alternative is that you got wedged in some dependency conflict.
I've sorted those out in the past, but only with help.
thanks will brb
You might have to apt-get remove, apt-get install.  Or possibly (not sure) apt-get purge.
apt-get remove doesn't remove any config files that the installer set up in /etc, apt-get purge clears those out.
Er, actually  I recommend using aptitude instead of apt-get.  Apt-get has some oddities about its syntax, aptitude tries to be apt-get flavored, but easier to use.
You did aptitude remove?
If this is a newly installed system, you might be best off starting from scratch (I know it grates, but...)".
Hm, sounds like you're out of my depth... sorry.
Maybe check back here later, see if somebody else can help you sort it out.
OR maybe on ##linux.
gparted?
Basically, what's happened is, one install is broken, if you install anything else, it will also try to finish that install.
And it will spit the error messages out at you.
